scenarioDescription:
The K2-18 Exoplanetary System


Overview

K2-18 is a star with 0.36 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.41 times its radius. It is located 124.03 light years away from the solar system.

K2-18 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the K2-18 system


K2-18 b

K2-18 b was discovered by the K2 observatory, in 2015-08, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-18 b is 8.926 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-18 b is 2.370 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, K2-18 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


K2-18 c

K2-18 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2017-12, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-18 c is 7.514 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-18 c is 2.650 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, K2-18 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-18, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the K2.
name: K2-18 - System With 2 Exoplanets
